title: Transfer Learning
content:
Transfer Learning is a machine learning technique where a model developed for a task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task. It's particularly effective in Deep Learning, where training models from scratch can be computationally expensive and require vast amounts of data.

The core idea is that knowledge gained from solving one problem can be applied to a different but related problem. For example, a model trained on a large dataset of images (like ImageNet) to classify objects has learned to extract general features (edges, textures, shapes) that are useful for many other computer vision tasks.

Common approaches in transfer learning:
1. Feature Extraction: Using a pre-trained model as a fixed feature extractor. The pre-trained convolutional base (for CNNs) is kept, and only a new classifier is trained on top of it.
2. Fine-tuning: Unfreezing some or all layers of the pre-trained model and retraining them with a very small learning rate on the new dataset. This allows the model to adapt its learned features to the specific nuances of the new task.

Benefits include reduced training time, less data requirement for the new task, and often better performance.

quiz.question: What is the main concept behind Transfer Learning?
options: Training a model from scratch for every new task
Reusing a pre-trained model as a starting point for a new task
Only training the output layer of a neural network

quiz.question: What is a key benefit of using Transfer Learning?
options: It can reduce training time and data requirements for new tasks

quiz.question: What does "fine-tuning" in Transfer Learning involve?
options: Unfreezing and retraining some or all layers of the pre-trained model
Applying a new activation function to all layers
